paragraphs.name: 2e05
paragraphs.text: At my first job I learned how to write html, css and some basic js and became a “developer.” When I took my second job I learned how to make illustrations and add animations to my designs. At my current job, I’m learning how to communicate my thoughts more clearly and build prototypes to better demonstrate my designs.

paragraphs.name: b81b
paragraphs.text: Trendy words/designs/clothes, etc. are exactly that: trends. They will, without a doubt, die out and look dated (Remember skeumorphic design). I try to avoid incorporating short-lived trends whenever I can in life and in my career.
If you enjoyed this article hit that heart ❤️ and share it with the world 👍

paragraphs.name: 484f
paragraphs.text: Even if you know option 1 won’t work in your head, showing the initial design is critical. Stakeholders won’t be satisfied until they can actually see its shortcomings. Usually a mashup of the two concepts will be the final outcome, but that’s better than executing a design you disagree with.

Disclaimer: I understand dribbble and other sites like it are meant to somewhat of a creative release for people. Therefore some of the work is strictly for fun and was never meant to be used in the real world. I’m not saying trying new things and exploring new styles is bad — but it’s not practical.

paragraphs.name: 75ae
paragraphs.text: Thanks for sharing this article. Showing two options: the first that directly meets most of the requirements from your primary stakeholder) and the second that shows any improvements over the expected design solution is a critical practice for designers who end up working with engineers, product managers, execs who have never worked directly with a designer before.
